Successful international models like the European Union's Youth Guarantee scheme can provide inspiration. India could implement a similar program at the district level, coordinating existing skill development and employment schemes to offer comprehensive support to youth seeking gainful employment or entrepreneurship.

item.title: Why collaboration model would work better for India in curbing Chinese footprints in neighbourhood
item.description:
The Indian Ocean Region, despite its militarization, remains relatively peaceful. China, however, is increasing its presence through various means, including naval deployments, dual-use infrastructure projects, and fishing activities. This has raised concerns about China’s intentions and its potential to exert influence over smaller nations in the region.
India, on the other hand, pursues a trust-based approach, focusing on capacity-building, humanitarian assistance, and regional cooperation initiatives. However, India's democratic processes and slower decision-making can hinder its effectiveness compared to China's more assertive model.
To counter China's growing influence, India needs to accelerate its engagement and demonstrate its commitment to the region through concrete actions and tangible benefits. Building trust and forging strong partnerships with its maritime neighbors is crucial for India to successfully implement its 'Neighbourhood First' policy and maintain a balance of power in the Indian Ocean.

item.title: Hamas ‘beehive’ leadership ensures survival despite Haniyeh’s killing
item.description:
Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in a suspected Israeli strike in Tehran, following a pattern of assassinations targeting Hamas' leadership. Haniyeh, despite being the organization's international face and advocating for negotiations with Israel, played a significant role in the recent escalation of violence.
His death is unlikely to cripple Hamas as it follows a structure designed to replace leaders, with senior members like Khaled Mashal and Yahya Sinwar, the Gaza leader, considered as potential successors. Sinwar, known for his ruthlessness, has earned the nickname "The Butcher of Khan Younis" and was last seen in a video emerging from a tunnel complex.
The article details other prominent Hamas figures who have also been eliminated by Israel over the years, emphasizing Hamas' ability to regenerate its leadership despite these losses. It concludes that the cycle of violence will likely continue as Hamas demonstrates resilience and adapts to new leadership.

item.title: Netanyahu seeks total war: Hezbollah is a sideshow, Iran is the real target
item.description:
Israel is escalating its conflict with Iran and its proxies, demonstrating a willingness to conduct targeted assassinations and airstrikes deep within enemy territory.
While these actions aim to weaken Hezbollah and Hamas, they risk provoking a wider conflict, particularly with Iran. Israel's strategy appears to be driven by a desire to force Iran's reaction, potentially justifying a strike on Iran's nuclear facilities. This aggressive posture, while projecting strength, lacks a clear strategic endgame and could lead to unforeseen consequences. The perpetuation of conflict also serves Netanyahu's political interests by consolidating his base and diverting attention from domestic issues.

item.title: How Ismail Haniyeh’s killing may weaken Hamas but not its ideology
item.description:
Recently, Ismail Haniyeh, the top leader of Hamas, was killed in an attack in Tehran. Hamas blamed Israel for the attack, while Israel celebrated the event. Haniyeh was a key figure in Hamas' political operations and was involved in ceasefire negotiations with Israel. His death has been met with anger by Palestinians, and there are concerns that it could lead to a further escalation of the conflict. The assassination is a significant blow to Hamas, but the group's ideology is unlikely to change, and it remains committed to its goals, including the liberation of Jerusalem.
The killing has sparked international concern, with some urging Israel to pursue a diplomatic solution and avoid further violence. Ultimately, the consequences of Haniyeh's death remain to be seen, but the situation in the region is highly volatile.

item.title: From Ukraine to Armenia, drones take centre stage in modern warfare
item.description: Drones have significantly changed modern warfare, offering precision, surveillance, and operational flexibility. Cost-effective compared to manned aircraft, they've been instrumental in conflicts like Nagorno-Karabakh and the Russia-Ukraine war. Technological advancements allow for secure control and precise strikes, making drones a powerful tool. However, the rise of AI in warfare, particularly Lethal Autonomous Weapon Systems (LAWS), raises serious ethical concerns. LAWS can identify, select, and engage targets without human intervention, leading to questions about accountability and the potential for unintended harm. International discussions aim to regulate these systems, but achieving consensus is challenging due to differing national interests and the ambiguity surrounding LAWS definitions.

item.title: Why US-Japan-South Korea trilateral partnership will withstand the test of time
item.description:
The US, Japan, and South Korea recently formalized their trilateral security cooperation with a historic memorandum signed by their defense ministers. This move comes amidst growing regional tensions, particularly North Korea’s nuclear and ballistic missile programs, the increasing US-China rivalry, and a more assertive China in the East and South China Seas.
The agreement outlines key areas of cooperation, including real-time data sharing on North Korean missile launches, joint military drills, and enhanced intelligence sharing. This strengthens the security umbrella for all three countries and aims to deter North Korean aggression. The trilateral cooperation also reflects a shared commitment to maintaining peace and stability in the Indo-Pacific region.

item.title: India–China ‘de-escalation’: New progress or new normal?
item.description:
Recent meetings and statements between Indian and Chinese officials highlight the ongoing tensions surrounding the India-China border dispute. While discussions on maintaining peace and making progress have taken place, China's actions, including the construction of a bridge near the Line of Actual Control, raise concerns.
Historically, China has prioritized its strategic and economic interests during border negotiations, and its current focus on maritime security, coupled with the militarization of its borders, adds complexity to the situation. India must remain vigilant and firm in asserting its position, preventing any "new progress" by China from becoming the "new normal" in this contested region.

item.title: Vietnamese PM’s India visit: How civilisational roots, geopolitical interests cement New Delhi-Hanoi ties
item.description:
Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh's visit to India aims to further strengthen the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership established in 2016. The two countries have witnessed a significant increase in bilateral trade, and defense cooperation is a key focus. India gifted a warship to Vietnam in 2023, demonstrating its commitment to deepening ties. Discussions during the visit are expected to include the acquisition of Indian BrahMos missiles and Akash surface-to-air missile systems.
Beyond strategic interests, shared civilisational history and cultural connections contribute to the growing trust between India and Vietnam. Both nations recognize the importance of multipolarity in the evolving global order and seek to build partnerships with like-minded powers to ensure lasting peace and security.

item.title: CCP’s Third Plenum: China has no blueprint to escape economic slowdown and is trapped in Xi Jinping’s vision
item.description:
The recent Third Plenum of China's Communist Party, presided over by Xi Jinping, outlined the country's policy direction for the next five years. The plenum emphasized a "new development philosophy" focused on high-quality growth driven by education, innovation, and technological self-sufficiency. Economic reforms aimed at strengthening the socialist market economy while maintaining state control were also highlighted, along with a commitment to green energy and fiscal reforms. National security received significant attention, underscoring the Party's commitment to strengthening its control over the military and defense capabilities.
The plenum's focus on state control and national security, coupled with the current economic slowdown, has raised concerns both domestically and internationally about the direction of China's future.

item.title: Why US policies fail to resonate with Arab public opinion
item.description:
Decades of US involvement in the Middle East, characterized by aid and military alliances, have not earned widespread Arab support. US policies often clash with regional sentiments, particularly its stance on Israel, leading to distrust.
The US has struggled to define clear goals and adapt to shifting dynamics, such as Iran's growing influence in Iraq. The frustration with US policies allows authoritarian regimes to manipulate public opinion by linking conflicts with the Palestinian cause. US interventions, perceived as heavy-handed and contributing to instability and refugee crises, further fuel anti-American sentiment. Iran and its allies amplify these grievances through propaganda, solidifying their position while US actions damage its credibility.
China's increasing diplomatic engagement in the Middle East, epitomized by its role in mediating conflicts, contrasts with the US's inconsistent approach and benefits China's popularity. The US faces a challenge maintaining its influence as regional powers seek diverse partnerships amid a shifting geopolitical landscape.

item.title: ‘Chanda mama no longer door ke’: Artemis dawns new space age as world gets ready with big moon plan
item.description:
The Artemis program, led by NASA, aims to establish a permanent human presence on the moon. This involves landing the first woman and person of color on the lunar surface by 2026, and building a lunar space station called "Gateway" by 2027.
The program seeks to utilize lunar resources like water and rare minerals, potentially powering rockets and future space exploration. Forty-three countries, including India, have signed the Artemis Accords, a set of principles for sustainable and transparent space activities.
While the US, with partners like SpaceX and Boeing, leads the initiative, China is also advancing its own lunar program focusing on resource exploration and utilization. Artemis is seen as a stepping stone for future human missions to Mars and beyond.

item.title: Quad’s quiet achiever: India’s growing footprint in the Indo-Pacific
item.description:
The recent Quad foreign ministers' meeting in Tokyo emphasized several key points.
Firstly, while India holds the chair this year, hosting responsibilities are flexible and driven by convenience, prioritizing pre-existing convenings.
Secondly, implementation of Quad initiatives, including those in the IORA region, Pacific Islands, and ASEAN, remains crucial, with a focus on disaster resilience, digital economy, and critical emerging technologies.
Thirdly, strategic challenges, particularly China's influence in the South China Sea, dominated discussions. The Quad supports ASEAN centrality and a robust code of conduct with China but remains concerned by China's actions.
Fourthly, attention shifted from the Ukraine crisis to the Gaza conflict, with all four members advocating for peace.
Finally, the Quad balances its work towards regional good with military coordination to address regional issues, reflecting India's nuanced approach - strategic congruence without formal coalition membership.

item.title: Why India needs to balance security concerns with neighbours’ sovereign considerations
item.description:
This article discusses India's approach to its regional security concerns and its interactions with neighboring countries, particularly in the context of China's growing influence.
India's "Neighbourhood First" policy aims to build strong ties with its neighbors based on people-centric interactions rather than personality-driven ones. While India addresses regional security concerns, it faces criticism from neighboring nations for expecting them to align with its security perceptions without sufficient consultation.
The article highlights instances where India's actions have caused friction with its neighbors, such as its defense agreements with countries like the US and pressure on them regarding China.
Despite these challenges, the author suggests that the Colombo Security Conclave (CSC) offers a platform for collective security dialogue and building trust among Indian Ocean rim nations, ultimately mitigating external influence and fostering a more cooperative regional security environment.

item.title: Unravelling the complexity of ADHD
item.description:
ADHD is often diagnosed alongside other mental health conditions. Studies show that a large percentage of individuals with ADHD also experience conditions like anxiety, depression, and oppositional defiance disorder. These co-existing conditions can exacerbate each other and lead to challenges in daily life.
One reason for this overlap is that symptoms of ADHD and other conditions can be similar, potentially leading to misdiagnosis. Additionally, genetic factors may contribute to the link between ADHD and conditions like autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
Recognizing the complexity of these co-existing conditions is crucial for effective treatment. A combined approach involving medication, therapy, and lifestyle changes can help manage symptoms and improve overall well-being.

item.title: Why India can’t afford not to engage with junta in Myanmar
item.description:
India's relationship with Myanmar's military junta is complex and fraught with challenges. While the junta's grip on power weakens, it remains a crucial ally for India due to its volatile region, porous border, and influence from Chinese-backed militias. India supports the junta primarily for strategic reasons, including counterbalancing China's influence, ensuring regional stability for initiatives like BIMSTEC, and tackling the narcotics trade.
Despite ethical concerns, India believes engagement with Mynamar is necessary and seeks a diplomatic path towards a future democratic framework. This delicate balancing act requires a combination of pragmatism and principle, as India navigates the complexities of Myanmar's situation.

item.title: The many diplomatic nuances of PM Modi’s expected visit to Ukraine
item.description:
Prime Minister Modi's potential visit to Ukraine stems from several factors. Ukraine desires international sympathy for its plight, and a visit from a major non-Western nation like India would be significant. India, with its close ties to Russia, has been urged to play a mediating role in the conflict.
Modi's recent visit to Russia angered the US, prompting India to consider this visit as a gesture of peace and diplomacy to Zelenskyy. This visit could also strengthen India's position on the world stage, counterbalancing China's involvement in peace initiatives.
India supports a peaceful resolution to the conflict and acknowledges existing mediation efforts by countries like China. Modi's visit, therefore, could be seen as a continuation of India's diplomatic efforts to find a solution that satisfies all parties involved.

item.title: Biden’s ‘coup for a coup’ to avenge his ouster from White House race
item.description:
Joe Biden's decision to drop out of the 2024 presidential race came after a series of setbacks, including a disastrous debate performance against Donald Trump and declining poll numbers.
Facing pressure from within his own party, including high-profile Democrats who wanted him to step aside, Biden ultimately conceded defeat. He claimed his decision was made in the "defense of democracy" and to "pass the torch to a new generation," endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris as his replacement.
Despite his stated reasons, Biden's move was widely seen as a face-saving attempt after his fitness for office was increasingly questioned. Several polls indicated that alternative Democratic candidates, including Harris, were performing better against Trump.
Biden's endorsement of Harris was seen by some as a strategic move to avoid an open nomination process that could have threatened party unity and led to a more contested race.
While Harris now holds the Democratic nomination, many remain skeptical of her ability to defeat Trump in the general election.

item.title: Paris Olympics 2024 | Tarun Tahiliani on India contingent's outfit: ‘Not a wedding’, but why digital print instead of weaves?
item.description:
Tarun Tahiliani has defended his designs for the Indian contingent at the Paris Olympics, emphasizing that they are not meant to be haute couture. Despite criticism about the use of digital prints instead of traditional weaves, Tahiliani maintains that the designs represent modern India and acknowledges the team’s preference for wearing what they are familiar with.
He further states that the uniforms have received positive feedback from industrialists and believes the different perspectives are natural. The designer stands by his choices, emphasizing that the focus should be on the athletes' performance rather than the aesthetics of the uniforms.

item.title: Dealing with Pakistan: How India can chart out a security roadmap for Kashmir
item.description:
This article outlines a multifaceted strategy for India to counter Pakistan's terrorism. It emphasizes strengthening security at infiltration points, particularly along the Jammu and Punjab border, and reviving human intelligence networks (HUMINT).
The author argues for a community outreach program to address alienation and concerns of various groups. Cracking down on Islamist outfits, reviving Village Defence Committees, and dismantling local support systems are also deemed crucial. A "carrot and stick" policy is proposed, incentivizing patriotism while applying tough measures against extremists.
The article concludes by advocating for strong diplomatic pressure on Pakistan, leveraging India's economic and military advantages, and potentially escalating to military action as a last resort to demonstrate the high cost of terrorism.

item.title: Jaishankar meets Wang Yi in Laos: Is thaw in Sino-Indian ties possible?
item.description:
India's External Affairs Minister, Jaishankar, met with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, on the sidelines of an ASEAN meeting in Laos. The discussions focused on resolving the ongoing border dispute along the Line of Actual Control (LAC).
Jaishankar emphasized the need for mutual respect, interest, and sensitivity between the two nations for normalcy to be restored. Both sides agreed to hold an "early meeting" of the Working Mechanism on Consultation and Coordination on India-China Border Affairs (WMCC) to further discuss border issues.
While previous attempts at de-escalation have seen limited success, both countries expressed hope for a swift resolution to the standoff, which has negatively impacted their bilateral relations.

item.title: No ‘Viksit Bharat’ without unleashing Green Revolution 2.0
item.description:
The focus should shift from discussions about capital gains tax to foundational reforms that benefit the majority of Indians. India's economic growth, while impressive, hasn't trickled down effectively, leading to significant income disparity.
Agriculture, crucial for a large portion of the population, requires urgent attention. Investments in technology, infrastructure, and research are needed to boost productivity and income for farmers.
Subsidies, while seemingly helpful, primarily benefit consumers, not farmers. Additionally, the government must consider a negotiated Minimum Support Price (MSP) system to incentivize crop diversification and provide basic income security.
Boosting agricultural incomes will have a positive ripple effect on the entire economy, especially the consumer market in rural India. Policymakers must prioritize reforms in agriculture, health and education to ensure a more equitable and prosperous society.

item.title: Trump 2.0: What it may mean for India-US relations
item.description:
A potential second Trump presidency could significantly impact India's relationship with the US. While Trump's economic nationalism might hurt Indian exporters through tariffs, it could also lead to increased US investment in India as companies seek alternatives to China. Migration policies are expected to be stricter, potentially impacting Indian IT professionals, students, and families seeking visas.
However, defense and military cooperation could further strengthen, benefiting India through technology sharing, arms sales, and strategic alignment against China in the Indo-Pacific. India's shared interests with the US in countering Chinese influence and terrorism could also lead to closer collaboration. Ultimately, the nature of the relationship will depend on strategic diplomacy and actions taken by both countries.

item.title: Paris Olympics 2024: Shame on Tarun Tahiliani for India contingent's ikat-inspired uniforms!
item.description: Tarun Tahiliani's Olympic uniforms for the Indian contingent faced sharp criticism for their unflattering design and lack of creativity. Ace badminton player Jwala Gutta highlighted the impracticality of the sarees for athletes, pointing out the discomfort and lack of pre-draped options. She also criticized the choice of colors and print, arguing that they didn't represent the beauty of Indian culture. Many felt Tahiliani, known for his expertise in other areas, did not do justice to the ikat weave, which could have been showcased more effectively. Critics compared the uniforms to cheap imitations found in local markets, lamenting the missed opportunity to represent India with a truly magnificent ensemble.

item.title: ‘Counter disinformation’ or betraying trust? US embassy’s meddling in India’s domestic politics deserves greater scrutiny
item.description:
This article discusses the US's attempt to influence India's domestic politics through seemingly benign initiatives.
It argues that while the US emphasizes a partnership of equals, its actions, particularly those undertaken by the US embassy in India, reveal a deeper agenda. The author highlights a workshop on "impactful content" hosted by the embassy, led by controversial figures linked to organizations with ties to the US deep state.
The article suggests these efforts, framed as countering disinformation, are actually attempts to manipulate public discourse and weaken the ruling BJP party, which the US views as a challenge to its liberal hegemony.
Further, it draws parallels to the Biden administration's alleged censorship of dissenting voices on social media platforms, implying that the US is employing similar tactics in India. The author concludes by expressing concern that these actions undermine the trust between the two nations, despite their proclaimed strategic partnership.

item.title: Hamas-Fatah deal: Truth behind China’s role as ‘global peace mediator’
item.description:
China recently brokered a peace agreement between Palestinian factions, including Hamas and Fatah, in Beijing. The agreement, welcomed by China and some factions, calls for a unified Palestinian government once war in Gaza ends. However, critics argue that the agreement is superficial and overlooks the deep distrust between the factions.
China's media is portraying this as a major diplomatic achievement, highlighting its role in mediating the Saudi-Iran rapprochement and suggesting its potential involvement in other conflicts. However, critics point out that the Saudi-Iran detente has yet to yield substantial results, and that China's support for Hamas and other groups designated as terrorists by many countries raises questions about its true intentions.
Some Indian commentators are also lauding China's peacemaking efforts, but critics argue that this overlooks China's own support for terrorism and its double standards on the issue.

item.title: Ongoing study reveals house sparrows in Uttarakhand follow human migration
item.description: A new study by the Wildlife Institute of India has revealed that house sparrow populations in the Uttarakhand Himalayas migrate along with the local villagers. The sparrows leave the high-altitude villages when villagers move to lower elevations for winter and return with them in the summer. This demonstrates a strong bond between the birds and humans. The study also found that sparrows living at higher altitudes are larger in size due to adaptations to the cold climate. Researchers are using bird banding to track the sparrows' movements and learn more about their nesting habits and food sources in these challenging environments.

item.title: More than just the Games: The big message the Olympics convey
item.description:
The Olympic Games, dating back to ancient Greece, remain a significant global event despite changing times. The Games promote sportsmanship and the pursuit of athletic excellence, transcending cultural and political boundaries.
They have historically facilitated dialogue and reconciliation between nations, as seen in instances like the participation of South Africa in 1992 and the marching of North and South Korea under one flag in 2000.
Beyond their symbolic value, the Olympics provide economic benefits to host countries, boost tourism, and raise global awareness of diverse sports. The cyclical nature of the Games, supported by sponsors, media, and fans, generates substantial revenue that is largely reinvested in the Olympic movement, ensuring its continued legacy.

item.title: America's Resolve Tibet Act and India as third polarity in Sino-Tibetan negotiations
item.description:
The Resolve Tibet Bill, signed into law by US President Joe Biden, expresses bipartisan support for Tibetan human rights and recognizes the historical inaccuracies of China's claims of Tibet's ancient ties to the country.
The bill, however, reiterates the US's "One-China Policy," potentially undermining its effectiveness in achieving genuine autonomy for Tibet. China vehemently protests the bill, reaffirming Tibet's status as an "inalienable part" of China. The Dalai Lama advocates for a middle-way approach, seeking autonomy within China, while emphasizing the need for international law and recognition of Tibet's historical status as an independent state. There are concerns over increasing repression in Tibet, including the recent closure of a prominent Tibetan vocational high school. India, with its ongoing border dispute with China, has a crucial role to play in any future negotiations regarding Tibet's fate. Observers believe that Tibetans should consider India as a key partner in their discussions with China.

item.title: Chinese checkers in West Asia: Why peace remains elusive in Gaza
item.description:
The recent developments in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, marked by China hosting Palestinian factions and Netanyahu's address in Washington, highlight contrasting approaches to peace.
China, seeking to position itself as a mediator, is working towards Palestinian unity, aiming for a unified approach under the PLO. This while Israel, led by Netanyahu, continues to focus on security concerns and firmly opposes any handover of Gaza to Hamas. The US, though officially supporting the Two-State Solution, has faced challenges in achieving progress due to intransigence on both sides.
While Netanyahu successfully garnered support in the US Congress by emphasizing Israel’s security needs, Senator Sanders remained critical of both Netanyahu and US policies.
China's efforts could potentially shift the balance, but achieving a lasting peace remains a complex challenge demanding nuanced solutions and compromise from all involved parties.

item.title: Modernisation and aatmanirbharta: Decoding the defence budget allocation 2024
item.description:
India's FY 2024-25 defence budget stands at Rs. 6.21 lakh crore, a slight decrease compared to the interim budget. Despite this, it remains the highest allocation among all ministries at 13% of the total budget. New Delhi aims to boost domestic defence manufacturing and reduce reliance on imports.
Recent years have seen a push towards indigenisation with over 12,300 items already localised. India's defence exports reached Rs. 21,083 crore in FY 2023-24, a significant increase. The government aims to raise military hardware exports to Rs. 50,000 crore by 2028-29.
Experts suggest increasing the defence budget to at least 25% of the total expenditure to meet the country's security challenges, including those posed by China and regional instability. The author also highlights the need to separate pay allowances and pensions from the core defence budget for better allocation and growth in the sector.

item.title: Rawalpindi’s jihad factory is bleeding Pakistan, and yet it won’t stop feeding terrorists
item.description:
Pakistan continues to promote terrorism against India while facing its own internal security challenges. Despite facing economic difficulties and a resurgence of terrorism in regions like Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan, Pakistan remains committed to using terrorism as a tool against India.
Recent terrorist attacks in Pakistan have highlighted the country's internal security struggles. This, however, hasn't deterred Pakistan from its anti-India stance. Army officials, while emphasizing their ongoing efforts against terrorists, have also raised concerns about the negative impact of "digital terrorism" and accused India of seeking to exploit Pakistan's vulnerabilities. Despite India's increasing focus on China as a strategic rival, Pakistan continues to view India as its primary concern. Experts argue that normalizing relations with India is crucial for Pakistan's future, as its ongoing enmity with India hinders its economic, social, and political progress.

item.title: How DRDO’s successful Ballistic Missile Defence test is critical to India’s security
item.description:
India successfully conducted a flight test of its Phase-2 Ballistic Missile Defence (BMD) system on July 24, 2024. This test demonstrated India's capability to intercept incoming ballistic missiles within a short timeframe of four minutes, highlighting the system's rapid detection, tracking, and decision-making capabilities.
The BMD program comprises two components: a exo-atmospheric system (Prithvi Air Defence or PAD) and an endo-atmospheric system (Advanced Air Defence or AAD). The Phase-2 test involved the AD-2 interceptor missile successfully intercepting the target missile at an altitude of less than 15 km.
This development is crucial given India's security concerns from neighboring nuclear-armed nations, Pakistan and China.
This success, combined with the procurement of Russian S-300 and S-400 missile defense systems, significantly bolsters India's defense capabilities and strategic posture.

item.title: India's quest to become leading maritime shipping hub
item.description: India's maritime sector is undergoing rapid expansion and modernization, aiming to position the country as a major hub for international trade. Recent advancements in port infrastructure, such as the Vizhinjam port, are enabling India to handle larger vessels and cater to the growing demands of global supply chains. Strategic location and massive coastline offer India a significant advantage in competing with established hubs like Singapore and Hong Kong. The government's "Maritime India Vision 2030" emphasizes developing world-class ports and transshipment hubs, fostering efficient logistics and making India a key player in the global maritime trade landscape.

item.title: As AI arms race heats up, India’s role will be crucial
item.description:
A global race for GPU dominance is underway, driven by the increasing importance of these chips for AI development. The US has implemented export controls on advanced AI chips to China, prompting a stockpiling effort by tech giants like Baidu and Tencent.
This competition has global implications, with countries like the EU, Japan, and South Korea investing heavily in their own semiconductor industries. India, while not a major hardware manufacturer, is positioning itself as a leader in the AI software and services space. Recognizing the importance of AI, India is focusing on several key areas:
* **Software Optimization:** Developing software solutions that maximize GPU efficiency. * **Cloud GPU Services:** Expanding access to high-performance computing resources through cloud platforms. * **Domestic Chip Development:** Investing in indigenous chip design and manufacturing capabilities. * **International Collaborations:** Leveraging partnerships to secure technology transfers and expertise. * **AI Research Hubs:** Supporting research and development in key AI areas. * **Talent Development:** Training and upskilling a large workforce in AI technologies.
India's strategy emphasizes its software strengths and collaborative approach to AI, potentially offering a unique alternative to the US-China tech rivalry.

item.title: How Trump’s return to White House can change dynamics in West Asia and Europe
item.description:
Given the current political climate and recent events, Donald Trump's potential return to the White House in November is likely to significantly influence US foreign policy.
Analyst anticipate greater focus on relations with China, potentially leading to trade tensions and a shift away from priorities in Europe and the Middle East. Regarding the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war, Trump might prioritize negotiations to end the conflict, potentially reducing US military support for Ukraine.
In the Middle East, a second Trump presidency could see continued backing for Israel, a harder line against Iran, and further escalation of the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict.

item.title: Global blind spot: China’s Uyghur crisis and the smokescreen of anti-India propaganda
item.description: China is expanding its surveillance and suppression of Muslims, starting with practices in Xinjiang and now targeting the Hui community in mainland China. This campaign, called "Sinification," aims to diminish cultural and religious distinctions among minorities and promote a unified national identity. The tactics include restricting religious practices, monitoring youth, and forbidding headscarves for civil servants. This escalation follows a pattern of previous persecution of Uyghurs in Xinjiang, where over a million have been detained in "re-education camps" and subjected to indoctrination, torture, and forced renunciations of their faith. Despite the human rights abuses, China deflects criticism by leveraging its economic power and investments in Muslim-majority nations. The international community must hold China accountable not only through words but also through concrete actions that support the Uyghur people's rights to freedom and dignity.

item.title: The spillover impact of student protests in Bangladesh and implications for India
item.description:
Student-led protests erupted in Bangladesh following the Supreme Court’s reinstatement of a controversial 30% quota for government jobs reserved for descendants of 1971 Liberation War freedom fighters.
The protests, which have turned violent, leading to deaths and injuries, demand the permanent scrapping of the quota system and accountability from Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. The government responded with internet shutdowns, mobile network restrictions, and curfews, while also detaining prominent protesters and opposition leaders.
The protests have impacted trade between India and Bangladesh, prompting the Indian government to advise its nationals and facilitate the return of over 4,500 Indians. India has also heightened security along its border with Bangladesh amid concerns about spillover effects. The situation has raised questions about the future of Bangladesh's internal stability and its relationship with India, particularly in light of China’s growing influence in the region.

item.title: 25 years of Kargil: Lessons on high altitude aerial combat against a bigger enemy this time
item.description:
The Kargil conflict serves as a prototype for India's potential future battlefield scenario against China. The conflict highlighted weaknesses in India's intelligence gathering and preparedness, particularly regarding Pakistan's infiltration plans. Despite initial setbacks and losses, the Indian Air Force (IAF) adapted its strategy, utilizing precision bombing techniques with laser-guided bombs and achieving decisive victories.
The Kargil War led to a comprehensive review of India's national security apparatus, resulting in the establishment of several key institutions and upgrades to military capabilities.
India faces a significant challenge in closing its military capability gap with China, especially in air power. While China is rapidly modernizing its military, India has experience operating in high-altitude environments and has been actively upgrading its fleet of fighter jets, transport aircraft, and missile systems. To effectively counter potential Chinese aggression, India must further strengthen its ISR capabilities, expand its fighter squadron strength, improve air defense systems, and invest in a robust drone fleet.

item.title: Ramification | Bangladesh’s quota protests: A test for Sheikh Hasina’s leadership
item.description:
Protests in Bangladesh over a reinstated quota system, which reserves government jobs for certain groups, have escalated into violence, leaving over 150 dead. The protests began after the High Court reinstated the quota system, but the Supreme Court later suspended the order.
The situation has been inflamed by Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's use of the term "Razakar" – a derogatory term for those who sided with Pakistan during Bangladesh's independence war – to describe the protestors, who are mostly students.
The protests have presented an opportunity for the Opposition to criticize Sheikh Hasina's government, and many Opposition leaders have been arrested. The resurgence of Jamaat-e-Islami, a proscribed outfit with transnational links and opposition to Bangladesh's creation, has raised concerns about the potential threat to regional peace and security.
India, meanwhile, is watching the developments closely, concerned about the potential impact on its own security and its Act East Policy.

item.title: Great power politics: BRI and IMEEC at the crossroads of global influence
item.description:
The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and the India, Middle East, Europe Economic Corridor (IMEEC) are major economic initiatives that reflect the changing global power dynamics. China's BRI aims to reshape the global order, while the US-backed IMEEC seeks to counter China's influence.
The rise of China and its economic ambitions have led to a shift in international relations, with the US employing strategies like IMEEC to maintain its hegemony. While both initiatives share goals of connectivity and economic growth, IMEEC might be more successful due to the US's democratic values, transparent financial sector, and global trust. Conversely, BRI faces accusations of debt-trap diplomacy and a lack of transparency. India has positioned itself outside both frameworks, advocating for a more inclusive world order.

item.title: India’s climate tightrope: Green growth for Viksit Bharat
item.description:
India presents a balanced approach to climate change, rooted in its ancient philosophy of harmony with nature. Recognizing the need to balance economic growth with environmental sustainability, India emphasizes human welfare and green growth. The country's per capita carbon emissions are lower than the global average, driven by initiatives like solar energy expansion and energy efficiency programs. Despite the challenges of transitioning to cleaner energy sources, India is committed to achieving its net-zero emissions goal by 2070.
Adaptation measures, such as strengthening agricultural resilience and protecting urban wetlands, are crucial for India's vulnerability to climate change impacts. India's sustainable lifestyle, emphasizing pro-planet choices, serves as a model for global climate action. The country aims to achieve its ambitious climate goals through domestic resources and international support, combining economic progress with environmental responsibility.

item.title: Reality check: Can India do anything about American interference in politics?
item.description:
This article discusses the influence of the West, particularly the US, on Indian politics through cultural means. The author argues that the US uses its soft power to promote its agenda by inviting and cultivating relationships with Indian influencers who are critical of the current Indian government. The article compares this to past instances of Western influence, citing examples of the Soviet Union and American involvement in India during the Emergency.
Despite acknowledging the challenges, the author suggests that India can use its global Indian community as a counter-force, highlighting their influence in various fields. The article concludes by emphasizing the ongoing cultural war being waged by the West and the need for India to develop its own strategies to counter it.

item.title: Is Iraq the missing piece in India’s corridor strategy?
item.description:
India unveiled the India-Middle East Economic Corridor (IMEEC), aiming to establish a trade route connecting India to Europe via the UAE, the Mediterranean, and onwards. However, this route faces concerns, particularly from Iran, which sees IMEEC as a threat to its economic influence through the International North-South Transport Corridor.
The article advocates for India to consider Iraq as a strategic alternative for trade security. Historically, India and Iraq have shared strong ties, evident in the large number of Indian laborers and expatriates working in various sectors of Iraq. The trade volume between the two nations has also doubled since 2020.
With Iraq enjoying increased stability and a dynamic business environment, the article proposes that India should strengthen its presence there. This includes fostering educational exchanges between universities, encouraging Indian businesses to participate directly in Iraqi projects, and exploring a third trade route through the country.

item.title: China’s inward turn: A path to stability or stagnation?
item.description:
China's recent economic and political events highlight growing instability within the country. Although pushing for self-reliance and national security, China's export-driven economy faces resistance globally and weak domestic consumption. This, coupled with a struggling property market and persistent corruption in the military, raises concerns about China's future stability.
Despite recent purges aimed at addressing corruption, the Chinese military appears to be compromised. The Belt and Road Initiative, once a symbol of China's global ambitions, is now facing backlash. While China attempts to maintain a facade of strength, its leadership faces serious challenges balancing economic growth with political control. This inward focus risks jeopardizing essential international partnerships and could ultimately stifle China's economic success.

item.title: Jammu terror attacks: Time to plug security loopholes and send Pakistan a strong message
item.description:
The article honors Captain Brijesh Thapa, one of four soldiers killed in an encounter in Jammu and Kashmir. Brijesh, a third-generation Army officer, embodied the spirit of the Indian Army, prioritizing his country and his unit's safety above all else. The article recounts his father's heartfelt tribute and the somber funeral ceremony.
It explores the ethos of the Indian Army, citing several other fallen soldiers like Lieutenant Manoj Pandey and Captain Vikram Batra, who exemplified bravery and selflessness. The author emphasizes the importance of remembering these sacrifices and urges the government to address the underlying causes of terrorism and strengthen security measures to prevent future incidents.

item.title: Kamala Harris’ advent infuses energy and hope in Democrats, but is it too late?
item.description:
Facing mounting pressure and declining popularity, Joe Biden finally withdrew from the presidential race on July 21st. His decision came after a series of events, including a poor debate performance, concerns about his physical and cognitive health, and a poll indicating his loss in November. Public figures like George Clooney and endorsements being withheld by key donors further pressured Biden to reconsider. Following the July 13th assassination attempt on Donald Trump, which bolstered the Republican's standing, and a diagnosis of COVID-19, Biden made the announcement.
He endorsed his Vice President, Kamala Harris, who has since received widespread support from fellow Democrats, including prominent figures like Bill and Hillary Clinton. While Harris is seen as the presumptive nominee, the lack of a transparent and competitive primary process has been viewed by some as a missed opportunity.

item.title: Budget 2024 creates a template for reforms in Modi 3.0
item.description:
The Union Budget focuses on five key areas: fiscal discipline, capital expenditure, regulatory simplification, job creation, and next-generation reforms.
The government aims to reduce the fiscal deficit to 4.9 per cent of GDP in FY25 and further to 4.5 per cent or less by FY26. A significant portion of the budget, Rs 11,11,111 crore, is allocated to capital expenditure to leverage the multiplier effect of infrastructure development.
The budget emphasizes streamlining regulations and simplifying policies to improve the ease of doing business and living.
Job creation is prioritized through an Employment Linked Incentive scheme with targeted initiatives to provide incentives for both employers and employees.
Finally, the budget outlines reforms for next-generation economic enhancements, focusing on land, labour, capital, and entrepreneurship, and leveraging technology to stimulate high growth and employment.

item.title: Budget 2024: A progressive approach to growth and welfare
item.description:
The Union Budget for FY 2024-25 emphasizes a balanced approach, combining high capital expenditure with substantial welfare spending. This strategy aims to maintain robust GDP growth while keeping the fiscal deficit in check. Despite global economic uncertainties, India's economy remains a bright spot, with low and stable inflation.
The budget prioritizes inclusive growth, focusing on the well-being of the poor, women, youth, and farmers. A key highlight is the Prime Minister's package, which encompasses five schemes to enhance employment, skilling, and opportunities for 4.1 crore youth over five years.
The allocation of Rs 1.48 lakh crore to education, employment, and skilling demonstrates the government's commitment to building a future-ready workforce. Through internships, employment-linked incentives, and skill loans, the government aims to empower youth, increase access to education, and generate new job opportunities. This forward-looking approach positions India for continued economic growth and development.

item.title: Budget 2024: Constructive welfare and not sops is the mantra for Viksit Bharat
item.description:
The budget focuses on a steady growth trajectory of 7% per year to achieve "Viksit Bharat" by 2047. It emphasizes a strong foundation through enabling measures rather than populist handouts. The government aims to improve farm income, youth skills, and create employment opportunities. The fiscal deficit is projected to be 4.9% of GDP, a commendable figure likely to attract foreign investment. Tax on foreign companies has been reduced to match Indian domestic companies.
Infrastructure allocation remains steady, and minor changes to personal income tax will benefit the middle class. Capital gains tax adjustments, while minimal, raise concerns about future potential hikes.
The focus on rural development, agriculture, and skilling is notable, with specific investments in natural farming, pulses and shrimp farming. The budget also aims to support the MSME sector and improve digital public infrastructure.

item.title: Budget 2024 lays blueprint for Viksit Bharat: Centre is facilitator, private sector, MSMEs drivers of growth
item.description:
The recent budget prioritizes government facilitation over direct financial responsibility. Instead of grants or investments, the government aims to incentivize and guarantee, as seen with potential loans for Bihar and Andhra Pradesh.
Similar approaches apply to youth employment, with incentives for employers and employees over direct job provision. The MSME sector receives loan guarantee schemes. To further illustrate this approach, the government’s new internship initiative involves no direct financial burden, instead relying on companies to utilise their CSR funds for training and allowances. This budget signals a shift towards facilitating growth rather than directly funding it.

item.title: Eco Survey 2024: Amid high growth India’s future appears bright, but a ‘grand alliance’ to tame unemployment is required
item.description:
The Economic Survey of 2023-24 highlights both positive and concerning aspects of the Indian economy. While the nation boasts a strong and stable economy, with projected growth between 6.5-7% and controlled inflation, there are significant challenges. Private sector capital formation remains slower than desired, foreign direct investment may face headwinds, and employment remains a concern.
The survey acknowledges the lack of reliable data on job creation, which hinders a clear understanding of the labor market situation. It emphasizes the need for a "grand alliance" between the central government, state governments, and the private sector to address these challenges and promote sustained high growth. This alliance would focus on boosting private sector job creation, particularly in manufacturing and services, and fostering innovation through collaboration between governments, the private sector, and academia.

item.title: US Sutra | Biden withdraws from presidential race, but road remains bumpy for Democrats
item.description:
US President Joe Biden unexpectedly announced his withdrawal from the 2024 presidential race, endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris as his successor. The decision came 100 days before the election, after calls from within the party for Biden to step down, and follows Donald Trump's announced candidacy and selection of JD Vance as his running mate.
While Biden cited fulfilling his current duties as president as his reason for withdrawing, the move leaves Democrats scrambling to prepare for the November election. Harris, who will face scrutiny over her record and performance as vice president, is now the frontrunner but faces an uphill battle against the popular Trump.
Many Democrats expressed disappointment with the late announcement, while Republicans seized the opportunity to attack Biden and his legacy. Trump, in particular, remained critical of the former president. Despite the support of some Democrats, including Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, the move has created uncertainty and divisions within the party.

item.title: Budget 2024 expectations: Empowering women farmers with technology to transform India's agricultural economy
item.description:
This article stresses the importance of empowering women in agriculture through technology to achieve a more equitable and sustainable food system. It highlights the significant contributions of women in agriculture despite facing systemic barriers in accessing resources, technology, education, and financial services.
The article argues that bridging the technological gap for women farmers is crucial for boosting productivity, increasing incomes, and ensuring their full participation in the agricultural sector's growth. It emphasizes the need for targeted policy interventions, including gender-sensitive credit facilities, training programs, and inclusive extension services, to address these disparities. The authors also advocate for increased women's representation in decision-making processes within agricultural institutions.

item.title: The horror of Razakars haunts Bangladesh again
item.description:
Protests in Bangladesh over the quota system in government jobs have turned violent, resulting in numerous casualties and arson attacks. The High Court's decision to restore a quota for the families of freedom fighters sparked the unrest.
The Supreme Court later reduced the quota, but protests continue, fueled by inflammatory rhetoric that invokes the term "Razakar," a derogatory term for pro-Pakistani collaborators during the 1971 Liberation War.
Critics accuse the protesters of being politically motivated and aim to discredit the Awami League government. The violence spread beyond Bangladesh, with incidents reported in the UK and UAE.

item.title: Microsoft's July 19 global outage highlights the critical need for stringent quality checks
item.description: A recent global IT disruption, affecting airlines, banks, and other sectors, was caused by a logical error in Crowdstrike's Falcon Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) tool. The error, stemming from a configuration file update, caused Windows systems to crash repeatedly, resulting in a widespread Blue Screen of Death (BSOD). While EDR solutions are designed to protect against evolving cyber threats by monitoring for suspicious behaviors, the Crowdstrike incident highlights the critical need for rigorous quality checks in software development. A misstep in the kernel-level code of the EDR sensor triggered the system crashes, showcasing the potential for even seemingly minor errors to have cascading consequences. The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of balancing speed of deployment with stringent quality assurance, especially in critical IT infrastructure.

item.title: The ICJ ruling on Gaza war and imbecility of rules-based order
item.description: The ongoing wars in Eurasia and the Middle East highlight the failure of the international rules-based order. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) recently ruled that Israel's settlement in the West Bank is illegal, but this advisory ruling is unlikely to change the situation on the ground. Both Israel and Hamas face limitations and challenges, and the region faces a volatile future with the potential for war to expand. Efforts for a ceasefire remain stalled due to lack of determination, equity, and enforceability. Millions are displaced, and countless lives are lost, with civilian casualties increasing the risk of further radicalization. The economic consequences are also significant, impacting countries beyond the immediate conflict zone. Ultimately, there is no clear winner in this conflict, and the situation poses a major challenge for the international community.

item.title: Sanity prevailed: Karnataka has done right thing by hitting pause button on local job quota bill
item.description:
The article criticizes employment reservation laws, using the example of Haryana's 2020 Act and Karnataka's recently proposed bill. It argues that such laws are unconstitutional, deter foreign investment, hinder labor market flexibility, and stifle innovation.
The author points to the success of Silicon Valley, fueled by immigration, as a counterpoint to the argument for local employment reservation. The article suggests that open labor markets, allowing for skilled workers from diverse backgrounds, are crucial for economic growth and innovation.
It concludes by expressing relief that Karnataka has paused its bill, highlighting the damaging consequences of restricting talent based on residency.

item.title: Two contrasting museums that showcase Mumbai’s spirit
item.description:
Mumbai offers a diverse range of exploration opportunities, including two contrasting museums. The National Museum of Indian Cinema, located in upscale Cumbala Hill, chronicles the history of Indian filmmaking from its earliest days to modern times. Housed in a 19th-century building with a rich history, the museum showcases iconic films, actors, and the evolution of technology.
In stark contrast, the BEST Transport Museum, situated in a bus depot in Sion, delves into the history of urban transportation in Mumbai. Through models and memorabilia, visitors can trace the journey from horse-drawn trams to modern buses, understanding the vital role BEST has played in shaping the city's growth and economy.

item.title: Sadhguru | Guru Purnima: When new possibilities open up
item.description:
Guru Purnima marks the first full moon of Dakshinayana, a significant day in yogic tradition. It commemorates the birth of the Adi Guru, the first teacher from whom yogic sciences originated. Adiyogi, the first Yogi, shared profound teachings with the Saptarishis, his seven initial disciples, on how humans can transcend limitations. This day signifies the opening of new possibilities for human consciousness.
